Award.AwardTitle: Physics and Astrophysics of Compact Binaries
Award.AbstractNarration:
In September 2015 Advanced LIGO made the first detection of the gravitational waves emitted from the merger of two black holes. In the near future, a network of Earth-based and space-based gravitational-wave detectors will observe binary systems composed of black holes and/or neutron stars over a wide range of masses and mass ratios. To realize the groundbreaking potential of gravitational-wave astronomy we must go beyond detection, extracting as much information as possible about the physics and astrophysics of the sources. This is the main theme of this project, that will study how Earth-based and space-based detectors can constrain the astrophysics of binary formation and further our understanding of strong-field gravitational physics. This award will support the gravitational physics group at the University of Mississippi, a leading research center located in a geographically and economically disadvantaged region, where engagement in the basic sciences is below national average. The project will strengthen collaborations between the gravitational physics community and the larger astrophysics community at a crucial time for the nascent field of gravitational-wave astronomy. The PI will train students and a postdoc in a highly interdisciplinary field that requires expertise in general relativity, astrophysics, data analysis and high-energy physics. The students and postdoc will benefit from interactions with a large international network of world-leading experts in gravitational physics.

The PI will study the astrophysical information that can be extracted from the spin-induced precession of black-hole binaries; explore the possibility to constrain binary formation scenarios using Earth-based and space-based gravitational wave detectors; study ultra-relativistic black-hole collisions as "numerical experiments" probing the limits of Einstein's theory; investigate the problems of absorption, scattering and superradiance in black-hole physics; and study whether compact objects can be used to reveal possible strong-field deviations from the predictions of general relativity. The long-term goals of this proposal are: (1) to explore the scientific payoff of the first gravitational wave observations: what can we learn about fundamental gravitational physics, and how will compact binary detections contribute to our understanding of the Universe? (2) to improve our theoretical understanding of compact objects, whether isolated or in binaries, in general relativity and in modified theories of gravity. The PI's group is part of the European Union-funded Research and Innovation Staff Exchange (RISE) Action "Strong Gravity and High-Energy Physics" (2015- 2020), which includes 8 nodes in Europe, the United States, Canada and Japan. This network will ensure that the students and postdocs funded by this proposal will be trained in a vibrant international environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the duration of this award the PI's group published about 60 papers, including 15 White Papers. The group made significant advances in our understanding of compact binaries, astrophysical tests of general relativity and gravitational-wave astronomy. Some highlights include: (1) population studies of stellar-mass compact binaries in the context of LIGO/Virgo and LISA, including the prediction that LISA eccentricity measurements could be used to distinguish field formation and dynamical formation scenarios; a study of (pulsational) pair instability supernovae; the exploration of the observational implications of second-generation black hole mergers; and a detailed analysis of spin orientation for black hole binaries formed in the field; (2) the development of various parametrized frameworks to study deviations from general relativity in gravitational-wave observations, including a "post-TOV" framework for neutron stars, as well as "post-Kerr" and parametrized ringdown formalisms to study deviations in black hole ringdown waveforms; (3) work on black holes in modified theories of gravity, including studies of the structure, stability and binary dynamics of black holes in Einstein-scalar-Gauss-Bonnet gravity; (4) various proposals to look for ultralight bosons (a possible dark matter candidate) through the gravitational-wave signatures of the boson clouds that they would form via superradiant instabilities if their Compton wavelength is comparable to the horizon radius of rotating astrophysical black holes.


The PI moved from the University of Mississippi to Johns Hopkins University in July 2018. The award provided partial financial support for 3 postdoctoral researchers and 7 graduate students at the two institutions. The one postdoc who left the group (Nishizawa) now holds a faculty job in Japan. Two students (Silva and Ghosh) defended a PhD at the University of Mississippi in the reporting period, and one of them (Silva) received the 2017 GWIC-Braccini Thesis Prize for the best Ph.D. thesis on gravitational waves. Students and postdocs were trained in cutting-edge scientific research and involved in international collaborations through three EU-funded research networks: an IRSES network, a RISE network and a COST action. They learned how to disseminate results through publications and conference presentations and they were encouraged to become independent researchers, producing several publications where the PI was not a co-author. In the reporting period the PI gave over 30 talks; he was the main organizer of four conferences, including the 2018 April APS Meeting; he served as Chair of the American Physical Society's Division of Gravitational Physics, and as a Divisional Associate Editor in Gravitational Physics for Physical Review Letters. At the July 2019 GR22/Amaldi13 Meeting in Valencia (Spain) the PI was named a Fellow of the International Society on General Relativity and Gravitation, and also voted as the new President Elect of Society.
